Detailed Description

Kinematics, dynamics, and other model functions of the Puma 560 robot.

The Puma560Model class provides functions related to the modelling of the manipulator. Specifically, generic functions are provided for:

  • Forward and inverse kinematics
  • Dynamics
  • Management of manipulator configurations
  • Jacobian functions
  • Mechnical limits (e.g., joint limits)

The kinematics algorithm is implemented exactly as shown in the paper "Computationally Efficient Kinematics for Manipulators with Spherical Wrists Based on the Homogeneous Transformation Representation"; Richard P Paul, Hong Zhang; International Journal of Robotics Research vol. 5 no. 2 1986 page 32.

The Jacobian was derived by Yongchun Fang.

Implementation of dynamics is based on the work done by Dennis Moses in his Master's thesis "Simulink Based Robotic Tool Kit for the PUMA 560 Robot Arm". The original source of this work was the paper "Dynamics of Puma Manipulator";Richard P Paul, Hong Zhang; American Controls Conference, 1983.

Finally, the DH constants are taken from the paper "A Search for Consensus Among Model Parameters Reported for PUMA 560 Robot"; Peter I Corke, Brian Armstrong.

Example Program: 

//======================================================================== 
// Project: Robotic Platform
// ---------------------------------------------------------------------- 
// Package: Manipulator Model Classes
// Authors: Markus Loffler
// Start Date: Wed Apr 18 12:43:15 GMT 2001
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------  
// File: Puma560Model.t1.cpp
// Example program for the class Puma560Model.
//========================================================================  
 

// ----- Standard Libaries -----
#include <iostream.h>

// ----- QRTS Libraries -----

// ----- Project Includes -----
#include "Puma560Model.hpp"
#include "Vector.hpp"
#include "RowVector.hpp"

 // =======================================================================
 // This program tests the forward and inverse kinematics functions of the Puma560.
 // =======================================================================
 
//======================================================================== 
// main
//========================================================================  
 
int main()
{
  Puma560Model model;
  
  Vector<6> jointPosition;
  int config;
  
  cout << "Input a Puma joint position (6 values in degrees): ";
  cin >> jointPosition;
    
  jointPosition = jointPosition * 0.017453292;
  // convert degrees to radians.
    
  
  //-----------------------------------------------------
  // Forward Kinematics
  //-----------------------------------------------------
  
  Transform x = model.forwardKinematics(jointPosition, config);
  // Get the transformation matrix T6
  
  cout << endl << "Forward kinematics from the PUMAModel: " << endl;
  cout << "x = " << endl << x << endl;
  cout << "Configuration: " << model.getConfigurationName(config) << endl;
  
  
  //-----------------------------------------------------
  // Inverse Kinematics
  //-----------------------------------------------------
  
  Vector<6> newJointPosition;
  
  model.inverseKinematics(x, config, newJointPosition, 0.1);
  
  
  if ( model.d_status.isStatusOk() )
  {
    newJointPosition = newJointPosition * 57.29577951;
    // convert radians to degrees
  
    cout << endl << "configuration: "<< config << " : " << model.getConfigurationName(config) << endl;
    cout << "joint angles are: " << endl << newJointPosition << endl;
  }
  else
  {
    cout << model.d_status.getMessageText() << endl;
  }
  
  /*
  // print all possible configurations.
  for (int config = 0; config < 8; config ++)
  {
    model.inverseKinematics(x, config, newJointPosition, 0.1);
  
    newJointPosition = newJointPosition * 57.29577951;
    // convert radians to degrees
  
    cout << endl << "configuration: "<< config << " : " << model.getConfigurationName(config) << endl;
    cout << "joint angles are: " << endl << newJointPosition << endl;
       
  }
  */
     
  //-----------------------------------------------------
  // Compute the joint limits
  //-----------------------------------------------------

  RowVector<6> min, max;
  for (int i = 1; i <= 6; i++)
  {
    min(i) = model.getMinimumJointPosition(i) * 57.29577951;
    max(i) = model.getMaximumJointPosition(i) * 57.29577951;
  }
  
  cout << endl;
  cout << "Minimum Joint Positions (degrees): " << min << endl;
  cout << "Maximum Joint Positions (degrees): " << max << endl;
  
  return 0;
}

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

Puma560Model ( const char * objectName = 0 )
 

The constructor performs no action. The class Puma560Model contains only functions. There are two static data members.

~Puma560Model ( ) [virtual]
 

The destructor performs no action.

Member Function Documentation

double getMinimumJointPosition ( int joint ) [virtual]
 

Determines the minimum position of a joint.

Parameters:
joint   The joint number (starting at 1).
Returns:
The minimum position of a joint in radians (revolute joint)/meters (prismatic joint).

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

Determines the maximum position of a joint.

Parameters:
joint   The joint number (starting at 1).
Returns:
The maximum position of a joint in radians (revolute joint)/meters (prismatic joint).

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

VectorBase * allocateJointVector ( ) [virtual]
 

Allocates a new vector of type Vector<numJoints>. The vector is allocated with "new" and needs to be freed with "delete".

Returns:
A pointer to the allocated vector.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

MatrixBase * allocateMatrixForJacobian ( ) [virtual]
 

Allocates a new matrix of type Matrix<6, numJoints>. This matrix fits exactly the Jacobian matrix. The matrix is allocated with "new" and needs to be freed with "delete".

Note that this function only allocates an empty matrix of the correct size, the jacobian is not initialized (use the functions jacobian() and inverseJacobianTranspose() for this purpose).

Returns:
A pointer to the allocated matrix.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

MatrixBase * allocateMatrixForInverseJacobian ( ) [virtual]
 

Allocates a new matrix of type Matrix<numJoints, 6>. This matrix fits exactly the inverse or transpose Jacobian matrix. The matrix is allocated with "new" and needs to be freed with "delete".

Note that this function only allocates an empty matrix of the correct size, the jacobian is not initialized (use the functions jacobianInverse() and jacobianTranspose() for this purpose).

Returns:
A pointer to the allocated matrix.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

int getNumJoints ( ) const [virtual]
 

Determines the number of joints of the manipulator.

Returns:
The number of joints.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

int getNumConfigurations ( ) const [virtual]
 

Determines the number of configurations that the manipulator has. This value is identical to the number of solutions of the inverse kinematics for a specific end-effector position (Considering a non-redundant robot).

Returns:
The number of configurations.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

Transform forwardKinematics ( const VectorBase<>& jointPosition,
int & configuration ) [virtual]
 

Performs the forward kinematics calculation (Calculates the end-effector transform and configuration from the joint position).

Parameters:
jointPosition   A vector containing the position of each joint in radians (revolute joint)/meters (prismatic joint).
configuration   This variable is set to the resulting configuration of the manipulator. Is it possible to omit this parameter.
Returns:
The corresponding 4x4 homogenous transformation calculated using the forward kinematics.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

bool inverseKinematics ( const Transform & endEffectorTransform,
int configuration,
VectorBase<>& jointPosition,
double epsilon = 0.1 ) [virtual]
 

Performs the inverse kinematics calculation (Calculates the joint position from the end-effector transform and configuration).

Parameters:
endEffectorTransform   The end-effector position and orientation
configuration   The end-effector configuration.
epsilon   A measure of how close the user wants to get to a singularity.
jointPosition   The calculated joint position vector (radians).
Returns:
false: if the robot is in near to a singularpoint (as much as epsilon) true: No singularity detected.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

void jacobian ( const VectorBase<>& jointPosition,
MatrixBase<>& jacobian ) [virtual]
 

Calculates the manipulator Jacobian from given the joint position.

Parameters:
jointPosition   The current position of the manipulator.
jacobian   The corresponding Jacobian matrix.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

MatrixBase<>& inverseJacobian ) [virtual]
 

Calculates the inverse or the corresponding pseudoinverse of the Jacobian matrix from the given joint position.

Parameters:

inverseJacobian   The corresponding inverse Jacobian matrix.

Parameters:

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

void dynamics ( const VectorBase<>& controlInput,
const VectorBase<>& positionInput,
const VectorBase<>& velocityInput,
VectorBase<>& accelerationOutput,
double samplingFrequency ) [virtual]
 

Calculates the dynamics of the manipulator in closed form: 

     qdotdot = M^-1 * { u - Vm(q,qdot)qdot - friction - gravity }

Note: The class Integrator can be used to integrate the returned acceleration to obtain the manipulator velocity and position.

Parameters:
controlInput   Control input applied to the joints (u)
positionInput   Current joint position of the manipulator (q)
velocityInput   Current velocities of each joint (qdot)
accelerationOutput   The calculated acceleration vector (acc).
samplingTime   The sampling time.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

void gravity ( const VectorBase<>& jointPosition,
VectorBase<>& gravityVector ) [virtual]
 

Calculates the effect that gravity exerts on each joint.

Parameters:
jointPosition   The current position of the manipulator.
gravityVector   The gravity vector. Each element of this vector is set to a value that represents the torque on this joint (revolute joint) or the force on this joint (prismatic joint).

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

void friction ( const VectorBase<>& jointVelocity,
VectorBase<>& frictionVector ) [virtual]
 

Calculates the effect that friction has on each joint. 

     friction = Fd * qdot + Fs * sgn(qdot),
where Fd is the coulomb friction and Fs is the static friction.
Parameters:
jointVelocity   The current velocity of the joints (rad/sec).
frictionVector   The friction vector. Each element of this vector is set to a value that represents the torque on this joint (revolute joint) or the force on this joint (prismatic joint).

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

void setStaticFrictionParameters ( VectorBase<>& staticFriction )
 

Sets the static friction constants for each of the joints of the PUMA. If not set, the following default set of values [8, 9, 1, 0.5, 0, 0] are used for static friction.

Parameters:
staticFriction   The static friction constants.

void setCoulombFrictionParameters ( VectorBase<>& coulombFriction )
 

Sets the coulomb friction constants for each of the joints of the PUMA. If not set, the following default set of values [4, 1.5, 1, 0.5, 0, 0] are used for coulomb friction.

Parameters:
coulombFriction   The coulomb friction constants.
